Question_1.Context: The study focused on the extraction and analysis of tobacco polysaccharides. The physicochemical properties and in vitro activities of the polysaccharides were investigated.
Question_1.Question: What was the primary method used to extract tobacco polysaccharides in the study?
Question_1.Source: The crude tobacco polysaccharide was obtained by hot water extraction, and purified and separated by DEAE cellulose chromatography column...

Question_2.Context: The study analyzed the monosaccharide composition of the tobacco polysaccharide fractions YCT-1, YCT-2, and YCT-3.
Question_2.Question: Which monosaccharide had the highest content in YCT-1?
Question_2.Source: The highly abundant monosaccharides in YCT-1 were mannose (3.209%), arabinose (8.016%), galactose (21.555%), glucose (58.274%), and xylose (3.141%)...

Question_3.Context: The study evaluated the antioxidant activity of the tobacco polysaccharide fractions using DPPH radical scavenging assay.
Question_3.Question: Which fraction showed the highest DPPH radical scavenging rate?
Question_3.Source: The DPPH radical scavenging rate of YCT-2 at a concentration of 4 mg/mL was higher than that of the other two fractions...

Question_4.Context: The study investigated the inhibitory effects of the tobacco polysaccharide fractions on α-amylase activity.
Question_4.Question: Which fraction showed a weak inhibitory activity on α-amylase?
Question_4.Source: Within the range of experimental concentrations (0.5–4 mg/mL), YCT-1, YCT-2, and YCT-3 exhibited a weak inhibitory activity for α-amylase...

Question_5.Context: The study examined the inhibitory effects of the tobacco polysaccharide fractions on pancreatic lipase activity.
Question_5.Question: Which fraction showed the highest inhibitory activity on pancreatic lipase?
Question_5.Source: YCT-3 showed the highest inhibitory activity (80.54%) at 1 mg/mL...

Question_6.Context: The study assessed the effects of the tobacco polysaccharide fractions on lipid accumulation in HepG-2 cells.
Question_6.Question: Which fraction showed the best effect in reducing lipid accumulation?
Question_6.Source: The lipid accumulation rates of the YCT-1 (500 μg/mL), YCT-2 (500 μg/mL), and YCT-3 (500 μg/mL) groups accounted for 86.46%, 85.58%, and 78.85%, respectively...

Question_7.Context: The study investigated the mRNA expression levels of lipid metabolism-related genes in HepG-2 cells.
Question_7.Question: Which fraction was more effective in up-regulating the mRNA expression level of PPAR-α, CPT1A, and CYP7A1?
Question_7.Source: Compared with YCT-1 and YCT-2, YCT-3 was more effective in up-regulating the mRNA expression level of PPAR-α, CPT1A, and CYP7A1...

Question_8.Context: The study analyzed the expression levels of miR-155-3p and miR-17-3p in the exosomes from different groups.
Question_8.Question: Which group showed a significant down-regulation of miR-155-3p and miR-17-3p levels?
Question_8.Source: Compared with the model group, miR-155-3p and miR-17-3p levels were significantly down-regulated in the YCT-3 group...

Question_9.Context: The study predicted the interaction sites between miR-155-3p and its target gene PPAR-α as well as between miR-17-3p and its target gene CYP7A1.
Question_9.Question: Which interaction was confirmed by the dual luciferase reporter gene assays?
Question_9.Source: The results showed that miR-155-3p and miR-17-3p significantly reduced the levels of PPAR-α WT and CYP7A1 WT in 293 T cells...

Question_10.Context: The study aimed to provide a new perspective for the comprehensive utilization of tobacco resources and the development of new plant-derived functional foods.
Question_10.Question: What was the primary focus of the study regarding tobacco polysaccharides?
Question_10.Source: The study aimed to provide a new perspective for the comprehensive utilization of tobacco resources and the development of new plant-derived functional foods from tobacco polysaccharides...
